701810f-a.text:
Soundview Avenue, west side, south of Lafayette Avenue, showing the Clason Point Military Academy, viewing southwestward toward the East River. On the left is the school building. The Academy was later abandoned and the
area developed into a residential section.
June, 1926
Brown Brothers
701810f-a.folder: Soundview Avenue & Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, NY

701808f-b.text:
Soondview Avenue, east side, at Lafayette Avenue, showing the old J. Husson house and farm.Beers' and Bien's Westchester County maps of 1867 and 1893, respectively, show it to have belonged to the Husson family.
July 30, 1928.
V.L. Sperr
(2)
A more distant view of the house from near Rosedale Avenue.
July 30, 1928.
P.L. Sperr

701809f-a.text:
Soundview Avenue, west side, south of Lafayette Avenue, showing the Clason Point Military Academy. The view is northward with the school and chapel appearing on the right. IR the center is the old Dominick Lynch Mansion, a stone structure. In this house was celebrated the first mass in Westchester County and the committee to design the American flag met here before proceeding to Philadelphia. The land in this area was owned by Lynch in 1793, part of which was sold,in the same year, to Issac Classon, whence the name is derived. Irg 1870 the mansion was bought by the Christian Brothers of the Catholic Faith, who changed it into the Sacred Heart Academy in 1883. It later became part of the
Clasen Point Military Academy.
June, 1926
Brown Brothers
701809f-a.folder: Soundview Avenue & Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, NY

701811f-a.text:

June 1926

701812f-a.text:
Soundview Avenue, west side, south Lafayette Avenue. Shown are the mrounds and buildings of the Clason Point Hilitary Acadamy. Cn the left, among the trees, is the Dominick LLynch House, where the committee to design the American flag met before proceeding to Philadelphia. The building in
the center is the chapel.
E. P. Chrystie  June 17, 1923
